member.name: P:Rubberduck.CodeAnalysis.CodeMetrics.CodeMetric.Name
member.summary: The name of the metric. Used for localization purposes as well as a uniquely identifying name to disambiguate between metrics.

member.name: P:Rubberduck.CodeAnalysis.CodeMetrics.CodeMetric.Level
member.summary: The aggregation level that this metric applies to.

member.name: T:Rubberduck.CodeAnalysis.CodeMetrics.ICodeMetricResult
member.summary:
A CodeMetricsResult. Each result is attached to a Declaration. Usually this declaration would be a Procedure (Function/Sub/Property). Some metrics are only useful on Module level, some even on Project level.
Some metrics may be aggregated to obtain a metric for a "higher hierarchy level"

member.name: P:Rubberduck.CodeAnalysis.CodeMetrics.ICodeMetricResult.Declaration
member.summary: The declaration that this result refers to.

member.name: P:Rubberduck.CodeAnalysis.CodeMetrics.ICodeMetricResult.Metric
member.summary: The Metric kind that this result belongs to. Only results belonging to the **same** metric can be aggregated.

member.name: P:Rubberduck.CodeAnalysis.CodeMetrics.ICodeMetricResult.Value
member.summary: A string representation of the value.

member.name: T:Rubberduck.CodeAnalysis.Inspections.Concrete.ObsoleteWhileWendStatementInspection
member.summary: Flags 'While...Wend' loops as obsolete.
member.why: 'While...Wend' loops were made obsolete when 'Do While...Loop' statements were introduced. 'While...Wend' loops cannot be exited early without a GoTo jump; 'Do...Loop' statements can be conditionally exited with 'Exit Do'.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething() While True ' ... Wend End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething() Do While True ' ... Loop End Sub

member.name: M:Rubberduck.CodeAnalysis.Settings.CodeInspectionSetting.#ctor
member.Summary: Default constructor required for XML serialization.

member.name: P:Rubberduck.Inspections.Abstract.InspectionBase.Description
member.summary: Gets a localized string representing a short name/description for the inspection.

member.name: P:Rubberduck.Inspections.Abstract.InspectionBase.InspectionType
member.summary: Gets the type of inspection; used for regrouping inspections.

member.name: P:Rubberduck.Inspections.Abstract.InspectionBase.Name
member.summary: The inspection type name, obtained by reflection.

member.name: P:Rubberduck.Inspections.Abstract.InspectionBase.Severity
member.summary: Inspection severity level. Can control whether an inspection is enabled.

member.name: P:Rubberduck.Inspections.Abstract.InspectionBase.Meta
member.summary: Meta-information about why an inspection exists.

member.name: P:Rubberduck.Inspections.Abstract.InspectionBase.InspectionTypeName
member.summary: Gets a localized string representing the type of inspection.

member.name: P:Rubberduck.Inspections.Abstract.InspectionBase.AnnotationName
member.summary: Gets a string representing the text that must be present in an @Ignore annotation to disable the inspection at a given site.

member.name: P:Rubberduck.Inspections.Abstract.InspectionBase.Declarations
member.summary: Gets all declarations in the parser state without an @Ignore annotation for this inspection.

member.name: P:Rubberduck.Inspections.Abstract.InspectionBase.UserDeclarations
member.summary: Gets all user declarations in the parser state without an @Ignore annotation for this inspection.

member.name: M:Rubberduck.Inspections.Abstract.InspectionBase.GetInspectionResults(System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: A method that inspects the parser state and returns all issues it can find.

member.name: P:Rubberduck.Inspections.Abstract.InspectionResultBase.QualifiedSelection
member.summary: Gets the information needed to select the target instruction in the VBE.

member.name: M:Rubberduck.Inspections.Abstract.InspectionResultBase.ToClipboardString
member.summary: WARNING: This property can have side effects. It can change the ActiveVBProject if the result has a null Declaration, which causes a flicker in the VBE. This should only be called if it is *absolutely* necessary.

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Inspections.Concrete.ExcelUdfNameIsValidCellReferenceInspection
member.summary: Locates public User-Defined Function procedures accidentally named after a cell reference.
member.why: Another good reason to avoid numeric suffixes: if the function is meant to be used as a UDF in a cell formula, the worksheet cell by the same name takes precedence and gets the reference, and the function is never invoked.
member.example: Public Function FOO1234() End Sub
Public Function Foo() End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Inspections.Concrete.IsMissingWithNonArgumentParameterInspection
member.summary: Identifies uses of 'IsMissing' involving a non-parameter argument.
member.why: 'IsMissing' only returns True when an optional Variant parameter was not supplied as an argument. This inspection flags uses that attempt to use 'IsMissing' for other purposes, resulting in conditions that are always False.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething() Dim foo As Variant If IsMissing(foo) Then Exit Sub ' condition is always false ' ... End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething(Optional ByVal foo As Variant = 0) If IsMissing(foo) Then Exit Sub ' ... End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Inspections.Concrete.ObsoleteCallingConventionInspection
member.summary: Warns about 'Declare' statements that are using the obsolete/unsupported 'CDecl' calling convention on Windows.
member.why: The CDecl calling convention is only implemented in VBA for Mac; if Rubberduck can see it (Rubberduck only runs on Windows), then the declaration is using an unsupported (no-op) calling convention on Windows.
member.example: Private Declare Sub Beep CDecl Lib "kernel32" (dwFreq As Any, dwDuration As Any)
#If Mac Then Private Declare Sub Beep CDecl Lib "kernel32" (dwFreq As Any, dwDuration As Any) #Else Private Declare Sub Beep Lib "kernel32" (dwFreq As Any, dwDuration As Any) #EndIf

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Inspections.Concrete.ObsoleteMemberUsageInspection
member.summary: Flags usages of members marked as obsolete with an @Obsolete("justification") Rubberduck annotation.
member.why: Marking members as obsolete can help refactoring a legacy code base. This inspection is a tool that makes it easy to locate obsolete member calls.
member.example:
Public Sub DoSomething() DoStuff ' member is marked as obsolete End Sub
'@Obsolete("Use the newer DoThing() method instead") Private Sub DoStuff() ' ... End Sub
Private Sub DoThing() ' ... End Sub

Public Sub DoSomething() DoThing End Sub
'@Obsolete("Use the newer DoThing() method instead") Private Sub DoStuff() ' ... End Sub
Private Sub DoThing() ' ... End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Inspections.Concrete.ThunderCode.KeywordsUsedAsMemberInspection
member.summary: A ThunderCode inspection that locates instances of various keywords and reserved identifiers used as Type or Enum member names.
member.why: This inpection is flagging code we dubbed "ThunderCode", code our friend Andrew Jackson would have written to confuse Rubberduck's parser and/or resolver. While perfectly legal as Type or Enum member names, these identifiers should be avoided: they need to be square-bracketed everywhere they are used.

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Inspections.Concrete.ThunderCode.LineContinuationBetweenKeywordsInspection
member.summary: A ThunderCode inspection that locates certain specific instances of line continuations in places we'd never think to put them.
member.why: This inpection is flagging code we dubbed "ThunderCode", code our friend Andrew Jackson would have written to confuse Rubberduck's parser and/or resolver. While perfectly legal, these line continuations serve no purpose and should be removed.
member.remarks: Note that the inspection only checks a subset of possible "evil" line continatuions for both simplicity and performance reasons. Exhaustive inspection would likely take too much effort.

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Inspections.Concrete.ThunderCode.NegativeLineNumberInspection
member.summary: A ThunderCode inspection that locates negative line numbers.
member.why: This inpection is flagging code we dubbed "ThunderCode", code our friend Andrew Jackson would have written to confuse Rubberduck's parser and/or resolver. The VBE does allow rather strange and unbelievable things to happen.

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Inspections.Concrete.ThunderCode.NonBreakingSpaceIdentifierInspection
member.summary: A ThunderCode inspection that locates non-breaking spaces hidden in identifier names.
member.why: This inpection is flagging code we dubbed "ThunderCode", code our friend Andrew Jackson would have written to confuse Rubberduck's parser and/or resolver. This inspection may accidentally reveal non-breaking spaces in code copied and pasted from a website.

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Inspections.Concrete.ThunderCode.OnErrorGoToMinusOneInspection
member.summary: A ThunderCode inspection that locates instances of 'On Error GoTo -1' statements.
member.why: This inpection is flagging code we dubbed "ThunderCode", code our friend Andrew Jackson would have written to confuse Rubberduck's parser and/or resolver. 'On Error GoTo -1' is poorly documented and uselessly complicates error handling.

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.AssignedByValParameterInspection
member.summary: Warns about parameters passed by value being assigned a new value in the body of a procedure.
member.why: Debugging is easier if the procedure's initial state is preserved and accessible anywhere within its scope. Mutating the inputs destroys the initial state, and makes the intent ambiguous: if the calling code is meant to be able to access the modified values, then the parameter should be passed ByRef; the ByVal modifier might be a bug.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As Long) foo = foo + 1 ' is the caller supposed to see the updated value? Debug.Print foo End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As Long) Dim bar As Long bar = foo bar = bar + 1 ' clearly a local copy of the original value. Debug.Print bar End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.AssignmentNotUsedInspection
member.summary: Warns about a variable that is assigned, and then re-assigned before the first assignment is read.
member.why: The first assignment is likely redundant, since it is being overwritten by the second.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething() Dim foo As Long foo = 12 ' assignment is redundant foo = 34 End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As Long) Dim bar As Long bar = 12 bar = bar + foo ' variable is re-assigned, but the prior assigned value is read at least once first. End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.AttributeValueOutOfSyncInspection
member.summary: Indicates that the value of a hidden VB attribute is out of sync with the corresponding Rubberduck annotation comment.
member.why: Keeping Rubberduck annotation comments in sync with the hidden VB attribute values, surfaces these hidden attributes in the VBE code panes; Rubberduck can rewrite the attributes to match the corresponding annotation comment.
member.example: '@Description("foo") Public Sub DoSomething() Attribute VB_Description = "bar" ' ... End Sub
'@Description("foo") Public Sub DoSomething() Attribute VB_Description = "foo" ' ... End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.BooleanAssignedInIfElseInspection
member.summary: Identifies redundant Boolean expressions in conditionals.
member.why: A Boolean expression never needs to be compared to a Boolean literal in a conditional expression.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As Boolean) If foo = True Then ' foo is known to already be a Boolean value. ' ... End If End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As Boolean) If foo Then ' ... End If End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.ConstantNotUsedInspection
member.summary: Locates 'Const' declarations that are never referenced.
member.why: Declarations that are never used should be removed.
member.example:
Private Const foo As Long = 42
Public Sub DoSomething() ' no reference to 'foo' anywhere... End Sub

Private Const foo As Long = 42
Public Sub DoSomething() Debug.Print foo End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.DefaultProjectNameInspection
member.summary: This inspection means to indicate when the project has not been renamed.
member.why: VBA projects should be meaningfully named, to avoid namespace clashes when referencing other VBA projects.

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.DefTypeStatementInspection
member.summary: Warns about Def[Type] statements.
member.why: These declarative statements make the first letter of identifiers determine the data type.
member.example:
DefBool B DefDbl D
Public Sub DoSomething() Dim bar ' implicit Boolean ' ... End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.DuplicatedAnnotationInspection
member.summary: Warns about duplicated annotations.
member.why: Rubberduck annotations should not be specified more than once for a given module, member, variable, or expression.
member.example:
'@Folder("Bar") '@Folder("Foo")
Public Sub DoSomething() ' ... End Sub

'@Folder("Foo.Bar")
Public Sub DoSomething() ' ... End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.EmptyCaseBlockInspection
member.summary: Identifies empty 'Case' blocks that can be safely removed.
member.why: Case blocks in VBA do not "fall through"; an empty 'Case' block might be hiding a bug.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As Long) Select Case foo Case 0 ' empty block Case Is > 0 Debug.Print foo ' does not run if foo is 0. End Select End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As Long) Select Case foo Case 0 '...code... Case Is > 0 '...code... End Select End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.EmptyDoWhileBlockInspection
member.summary: Identifies empty 'Do...Loop While' blocks that can be safely removed.
member.why: Dead code should be removed. A loop without a body is usually redundant.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As Long) Do ' no executable statement... Loop While foo < 100 End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As Long) Do Debug.Print foo Loop While foo < 100 End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.EmptyElseBlockInspection
member.summary: Identifies empty 'Else' blocks that can be safely removed.
member.why: Empty code blocks are redundant, dead code that should be removed. They can also be misleading about their intent: an empty block may be signalling an unfinished thought or an oversight.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As Boolean) If foo Then ' ... Else End If End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As Boolean) If foo Then ' ... End If End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.EmptyForEachBlockInspection
member.summary: Identifies empty 'For Each...Next' blocks that can be safely removed.
member.why: Dead code should be removed. A loop without a body is usually redundant.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething() Dim sheet As Worksheet For Each sheet In ThisWorkbook.Worksheets ' no executable statement... Next End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething() Dim sheet As Worksheet For Each sheet In ThisWorkbook.Worksheets Debug.Print sheet.Name Next End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.EmptyForLoopBlockInspection
member.summary: Identifies empty 'For...Next' blocks that can be safely removed.
member.why: Dead code should be removed. A loop without a body is usually redundant.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As Long) Dim i As Long For i = 0 To foo ' no executable statement... Next End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As Long) Dim i As Long For i = 0 To foo Debug.Print i Next End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.EmptyIfBlockInspection
member.summary: Identifies empty 'If' blocks.
member.why: Conditional expression is inverted; there would not be a need for an 'Else' block otherwise.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As Boolean) If foo Then Else ' ... End If End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As Boolean) If Not foo Then ' ... End If End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.EmptyModuleInspection
member.summary: Flags empty code modules.
member.why: An empty module does not need to exist and can be safely removed.

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.EmptyStringLiteralInspection
member.summary: Flags uses of an empty string literal ("").
member.why: Standard library constant 'vbNullString' is more explicit about its intent, and should be preferred to a string literal. While the memory gain is meaningless, an empty string literal still takes up 2 bytes of memory, but 'vbNullString' is a null string pointer, and doesn't.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As String) If foo = "" Then ' ... End If End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As String) If foo = vbNullString Then ' ... End If End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.EmptyWhileWendBlockInspection
member.summary: Identifies empty 'While...Wend' blocks that can be safely removed.
member.why: Dead code should be removed. A loop without a body is usually redundant.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As Long) While foo < 100 'no executable statements... would be an infinite loop if entered Wend End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As Long) While foo < 100 foo = foo + 1 Wend End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.EncapsulatePublicFieldInspection
member.summary: Flags publicly exposed instance fields.
member.why: Instance fields are the implementation details of a object's internal state; exposing them directly breaks encapsulation. Often, an object only needs to expose a 'Get' procedure to expose an internal instance field.
member.example: Public Foo As Long

Private internalFoo As Long
Public Property Get Foo() As Long Foo = internalFoo End Property

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.ApplicationWorksheetFunctionInspection
member.summary: Warns about late-bound WorksheetFunction calls made against the extended interface of the Application object.
member.why: An early-bound, equivalent function likely exists in the object returned by the Application.WorksheetFunction property; late-bound member calls will fail at run-time with error 438 if there is a typo (a typo fails to compile for an early-bound member call). Late-bound worksheet functions will return a Variant/Error given invalid inputs; the equivalent early-bound member calls raise a more VB-idiomatic runtime error given the same invalid inputs. A Variant/Error value cannot be coerced into any other data type, be it for assignment or comparison. Trying to compare or assign a Variant/Error to another data type will throw error 13 "type mismatch" at run-time. Consider using the early-bound equivalent function instead.
member.example:
Private Sub Example() Debug.Print Application.Sum(Array(1, 2, 3), 4, 5, "ABC") ' outputs "Error 2015"
Dim foo As Long foo = Application.Sum(Array(1, 2, 3), 4, 5, "ABC") ' error 13 "type mismatch". Variant/Error can't be coerced to Long.
If Application.Sum(Array(1, 2, 3), 4, 5, "ABC") > 15 Then ' won't run, error 13 "type mismatch" will be thrown when Variant/Error is compared to an Integer. End If End Sub

Private Sub Example() Debug.Print Application.WorksheetFunction.Sum(Array(1, 2, 3), 4, 5, "ABC") ' throws error 1004
Dim foo As Long foo = Application.WorksheetFunction.Sum(Array(1, 2, 3), 4, 5, "ABC") ' throws error 1004
If Application.WorksheetFunction.Sum(Array(1, 2, 3), 4, 5, "ABC") > 15 Then ' throws error 1004 ' won't run, error 1004 is thrown when "ABC" is processed by WorksheetFunction.Sum, before it returns. End If End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.ExcelMemberMayReturnNothingInspection
member.summary: Locates instances of member calls made against the result of a Range.Find/FindNext/FindPrevious method, without prior validation.
member.why: Range.Find methods return a Range object reference that refers to the cell containing the search string; this object reference will be Nothing if the search didn't turn up any results, and a member call against Nothing will raise run-time error 91.
member.example:
Private Sub Example() Dim foo As Range Set foo = Sheet1.Range("A:A").Find("Test") ' foo is Nothing if there are no results MsgBox foo.Address ' Range.Address member call should be flagged.
Dim rowIndex As Range rowIndex = Sheet1.Range("A:A").Find("Test").Row ' Range.Row member call should be flagged. End Sub
Private Sub Example() Dim foo As Range Set foo = Sheet1.Range("A:A").Find("Test") If Not foo Is Nothing Then MsgBox foo.Address ' Range.Address member call is safe. End If End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.ImplicitActiveSheetReferenceInspection
member.summary: Locates unqualified Worksheet.Range/Cells/Columns/Rows member calls that implicitly refer to ActiveSheet.
member.why: Implicit references to the active worksheet rarely mean to be working with *whatever worksheet is currently active*. By explicitly qualifying these member calls with a specific Worksheet object, the assumptions are removed, the code is more robust, and will be less likely to throw run-time error 1004 or produce unexpected results when the active sheet isn't the expected one.
member.example: Private Sub Example() Dim foo As Range Set foo = Sheet1.Range(Cells(1, 1), Cells(1, 10)) ' Worksheet.Cells implicitly from ActiveSheet; error 1004 if that isn't Sheet1. End Sub
Private Sub Example() Dim foo As Range With Sheet1 Set foo = .Range(.Cells(1, 1), .Cells(1, 10)) ' all member calls are made against the With block object End With End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.ImplicitActiveWorkbookReferenceInspection
member.summary: Locates unqualified Workbook.Worksheets/Sheets/Names member calls that implicitly refer to ActiveWorkbook.
member.why: Implicit references to the active workbook rarely mean to be working with *whatever workbook is currently active*. By explicitly qualifying these member calls with a specific Workbook object, the assumptions are removed, the code is more robust, and will be less likely to throw run-time error 1004 or produce unexpected results when the active workbook isn't the expected one.
member.example: Private Sub Example() Dim summarySheet As Worksheet Set summarySheet = Worksheets("Summary") ' unqualified Worksheets is implicitly querying the active workbook's Worksheets collection. End Sub
Private Sub Example(ByVal book As Workbook) Dim summarySheet As Worksheet Set summarySheet = book.Worksheets("Summary") End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.SheetAccessedUsingStringInspection
member.summary: Locates ThisWorkbook.Worksheets and ThisWorkbook.Sheets calls that appear to be dereferencing a worksheet that is already accessible at compile-time with a global-scope identifier.
member.why: Sheet names can be changed by the user, as can a worksheet's index in ThisWorkbook.Worksheets. Worksheets that exist in ThisWorkbook at compile-time are more reliably programmatically accessed using their CodeName, which cannot be altered by the user without accessing the VBE and altering the VBA project.
member.remarks: Inspection only evaluates hard-coded string literals; string-valued expressions evaluating into a sheet name are ignored.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething() Dim sheet As Worksheet Set sheet = ThisWorkbook.Worksheets("Sheet1") ' Sheet "Sheet1" exists at compile-time sheet.Range("A1").Value = 42 End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething() Sheet1.Range("A1").Value = 42 ' TODO rename Sheet1 to meaningful name End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.FunctionReturnValueNotUsedInspection
member.summary: Warns when a user function's return value is never used, at any of its call sites.
member.why: A 'Function' procedure normally means its return value to be captured and consumed by the calling code. It's possible that not all call sites need the return value, but if the value is systematically discarded then this means the function is side-effecting, and thus should probably be a 'Sub' procedure instead.
member.example:
Public Sub DoSomething() GetFoo ' return value is not captured End Sub
Private Function GetFoo() As Long GetFoo = 42 End Function

Public Sub DoSomething() Dim foo As Long foo = GetFoo End Sub
Private Function GetFoo() As Long GetFoo = 42 End Function

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.HostSpecificExpressionInspection
member.summary: Warns about host-evaluated square-bracketed expressions.
member.why: Host-evaluated expressions should be implementable using the host application's object model. If the expression yields an object, member calls against that object are late-bound.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething() [A1].Value = 42 End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething() ActiveSheet.Range("A1").Value = 42 End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.HungarianNotationInspection
member.summary: Flags identifiers that use [Systems] Hungarian Notation prefixes.
member.why: Systems Hungarian (encoding data types in variable names) stemmed from a misunderstanding of what its inventor meant when they described that prefixes identified the "kind" of variable in a naming scheme dubbed Apps Hungarian. Modern naming conventions in all programming languages heavily discourage the use of Systems Hungarian prefixes.
member.example:
Public Sub DoSomething() Dim bFoo As Boolean, blnFoo As Boolean Dim intBar As Long ' which is correct? the int or the Long? End Sub
Private Function fnlngGetFoo() As Long fnlngGetFoo = 42 End Function

Public Sub DoSomething() Dim foo As Boolean, isFoo As Boolean Dim bar As long End Sub
Private Function GetFoo() As Long GetFoo = 42 End Function

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.IllegalAnnotationInspection
member.summary: Flags invalid Rubberduck annotation comments.
member.why: Rubberduck is correctly parsing an annotation, but that annotation is illegal in that context.
member.example:
Option Explicit
Public Sub DoSomething() '@Folder("Module1.DoSomething") Dim foo As Long End Sub

'@Folder("Module1.DoSomething") Option Explicit
Public Sub DoSomething() Dim foo As Long End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.ImplicitDefaultMemberAssignmentInspection
member.summary: Identifies implicit default member calls.
member.why: Code should do what it says, and say what it does. Implicit default member calls generally do the opposite of that.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething() ActiveSheet.Range("A1") = 42 ' implicit assignment to 'Range.[_default]'. End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething() ActiveSheet.Range("A1").Value = 42 End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.ImplicitPublicMemberInspection
member.summary: Highlights implicit Public access modifiers in user code.
member.why: In modern VB (VB.NET), the implicit access modifier is Private, as it is in most other programming languages. Making the Public modifiers explicit can help surface potentially unexpected language defaults.
member.example: Sub DoSomething() ' ... End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething() ' ... End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.ImplicitVariantReturnTypeInspection
member.summary: Warns about 'Function' and 'Property Get' procedures that don't have an explicit return type.
member.why: All functions return something, whether a type is specified or not. The implicit default is 'Variant'.
member.example: Public Function GetFoo() GetFoo = 42 End Function
Public Function GetFoo() As Long GetFoo = 42 End Function

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.IntegerDataTypeInspection
member.summary: Identifies obsolete 16-bit integer variables.
member.why: Modern processors are optimized for processing 32-bit integers; internally, a 16-bit integer is still stored as a 32-bit value. Unless code is interacting with APIs that require a 16-bit integer, a Long (32-bit integer) should be used instead.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething() Dim rowCount As Integer rowCount = Sheet1.Rows.Count ' overflow: maximum 16-bit signed integer value is only 32,767 (2^15-1)! End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething() Dim rowCount As Long rowCount = Sheet1.Rows.Count ' all good: maximum 32-bit signed integer value is 2,147,483,647 (2^31-1)! End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.IsMissingOnInappropriateArgumentInspection
member.summary: Identifies uses of 'IsMissing' involving non-variant, non-optional, or array parameters.
member.why: 'IsMissing' only returns True when an optional Variant parameter was not supplied as an argument. This inspection flags uses that attempt to use 'IsMissing' for other purposes, resulting in conditions that are always False.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As Long = 0) If IsMissing(foo) Then Exit Sub ' condition is always false ' ... End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething(Optional ByVal foo As Variant = 0) If IsMissing(foo) Then Exit Sub ' ... End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.LineLabelNotUsedInspection
member.summary: Identifies line labels that are never referenced, and therefore superfluous.
member.why: Line labels are useful for GoTo, GoSub, Resume, and On Error statements; but the intent of a line label can be confusing if it isn't referenced by any such instruction.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething() ' On Error GoTo ErrHandler ' (commented-out On Error statement leaves line label unreferenced) ' ... Exit Sub ErrHandler: ' ... End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething() On Error GoTo ErrHandler ' ... Exit Sub ErrHandler: ' ... End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.MemberNotOnInterfaceInspection
member.summary: Warns about member calls against an extensible interface, that cannot be validated at compile-time.
member.why: Extensible COM types can have members attached at run-time; VBA cannot bind these member calls at compile-time. If there is an early-bound alternative way to achieve the same result, it should be preferred.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal adoConnection As ADODB.Connection) adoConnection.SomeStoredProcedure 42 End Sub

Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal adoConnection As ADODB.Connection) Dim adoCommand As ADODB.Command Set adoCommand.ActiveConnection = adoConnection adoCommand.CommandText = "SomeStoredProcedure" adoCommand.CommandType = adCmdStoredProc adoCommand.Parameters.Append adocommand.CreateParameter(Value:=42) adoCommand.Execute End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.MissingAnnotationArgumentInspection
member.summary: Warns about a malformed Rubberduck annotation that is missing an argument.
member.why: Some annotations require arguments; if the argument isn't specified, the annotation is nothing more than an obscure comment.
member.example: '@Folder '@ModuleDescription Option Explicit ' ...
'@Folder("MyProject.XYZ") '@ModuleDescription("This module does XYZ") Option Explicit ' ...

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.MissingAttributeInspection
member.summary: Indicates that a Rubberduck annotation is documenting the presence of a VB attribute that is actually missing.
member.why: Rubberduck annotations mean to document the presence of hidden VB attributes; this inspection flags annotations that do not have a corresponding VB attribute.
member.example: '@Description("foo") Public Sub DoSomething() ' ... End Sub
'@Description("foo") Public Sub DoSomething() Attribute VB_Description = "foo" ' ... End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.MissingMemberAnnotationInspection
member.summary: Indicates that a hidden VB attribute is present for a member, but no Rubberduck annotation is documenting it.
member.why: Rubberduck annotations mean to document the presence of hidden VB attributes; this inspection flags members that do not have a Rubberduck annotation corresponding to the hidden VB attribute.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething() Attribute VB_Description = "foo" ' ... End Sub
'@Description("foo") Public Sub DoSomething() Attribute VB_Description = "foo" ' ... End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.MissingModuleAnnotationInspection
member.summary: Indicates that a hidden VB attribute is present for a module, but no Rubberduck annotation is documenting it.
member.why: Rubberduck annotations mean to document the presence of hidden VB attributes; this inspection flags modules that do not have a Rubberduck annotation corresponding to the hidden VB attribute.
member.example: Attribute VB_PredeclaredId = True Option Explicit ' ...
Attribute VB_PredeclaredId = True '@PredeclaredId Option Explicit ' ...

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.ModuleScopeDimKeywordInspection
member.summary: Warns about module-level declarations made using the 'Dim' keyword.
member.why: Private module variables should be declared using the 'Private' keyword. While 'Dim' is also legal, it should preferably be restricted to declarations of procedure-scoped local variables, for consistency, since public module variables are declared with the 'Public' keyword.
member.example: Option Explicit Dim foo As Long ' ...
Option Explicit Private foo As Long ' ...

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.ModuleWithoutFolderInspection
member.summary: Indicates that a user module is missing a @Folder Rubberduck annotation.
member.why: Modules without a custom @Folder annotation will be grouped under the default folder in the Code Explorer toolwindow. By specifying a custom @Folder annotation, modules can be organized by functionality rather than simply listed.
member.example: Option Explicit ' ...
'@Folder("Foo") Option Explicit ' ...

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.MoveFieldCloserToUsageInspection
member.summary: Locates module-level fields that can be moved to a smaller scope.
member.why: Module-level variables that are only used in a single procedure can often be declared in that procedure's scope. Declaring variables closer to where they are used generally makes the code easier to follow.
member.example:
Option Explicit Private foo As Long
Public Sub DoSomething() foo = 42 Debug.Print foo ' module variable is only used in this scope End Sub

Option Explicit
Public Sub DoSomething() Dim foo As Long ' local variable only used in this scope foo = 42 Debug.Print foo End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.MultilineParameterInspection
member.summary: Flags parameters declared across multiple physical lines of code.
member.why: When splitting a long list of parameters across multiple lines, care should be taken to avoid splitting a parameter declaration in two.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As Long, ByVal _ bar As Long) ' ... End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As Long, _ ByVal bar As Long) ' ... End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.MultipleDeclarationsInspection
member.summary: Flags declaration statements spanning multiple physical lines of code.
member.why: Declaration statements should generally declare a single variable.
member.example: Dim foo As Long, bar As Long
Dim foo As Long Dim bar As Long

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.NonReturningFunctionInspection
member.summary: Warns about 'Function' and 'Property Get' procedures whose return value is not assigned.
member.why: Both 'Function' and 'Property Get' accessors should always return something. Omitting the return assignment is likely a bug.
member.example: Public Function GetFoo() As Long Dim foo As Long foo = 42 'function will always return 0 End Function
Public Function GetFoo() As Long Dim foo As Long foo = 42 GetFoo = foo End Function

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.NonReturningFunctionInspection.FunctionReturnValueAssignmentLocator
member.summary: A visitor that visits a member's body and returns true if any LET statement (assignment) is assigning the specified name.

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.ObjectVariableNotSetInspection
member.summary: Warns about assignments that appear to be assigning an object reference without the 'Set' keyword.
member.why: Omitting the 'Set' keyword will Let-coerce the right-hand side (RHS) of the assignment expression. If the RHS is an object variable, then the assignment is implicitly assigning to that object's default member, which may raise run-time error 91 at run-time.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething() Dim foo As Object foo = New Collection ' ... End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething() Dim foo As Object Set foo = New Collection ' ... End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.ObsoleteCallStatementInspection
member.summary: Locates explicit 'Call' statements.
member.why: The 'Call' keyword is obsolete and redundant, since call statements are legal and generally more consistent without it.
member.example:
Public Sub Test() Call DoSomething(42) End Sub
Private Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As Long) ' ... End Sub

Public Sub Test() DoSomething 42 End Sub
Private Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As Long) ' ... End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.ObsoleteCommentSyntaxInspection
member.summary: Locates legacy 'Rem' comments.
member.why: Modern VB comments use a single quote character (') to denote the beginning of a comment: the legacy 'Rem' syntax is obsolete.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething() Rem this comment is using an obsolete legacy syntax End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething() ' this comment is using the modern comment syntax End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.ObsoleteErrorSyntaxInspection
member.summary: Locates legacy 'Error' statements.
member.why: The legacy syntax is obsolete; prefer 'Err.Raise' instead.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething() Error 5 ' raises run-time error 5 End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething() Err.Raise 5 ' raises run-time error 5 End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.ObsoleteGlobalInspection
member.summary: Locates legacy 'Global' declaration statements.
member.why: The legacy syntax is obsolete; use the 'Public' keyword instead.
member.example: Option Explicit Global Foo As Long
Option Explicit Public Foo As Long

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.ObsoleteLetStatementInspection
member.summary: Locates explicit 'Let' assignments.
member.why: The legacy syntax is obsolete/redundant; prefer implicit Let-coercion instead.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething() Dim foo As Long Let foo = 42 ' explicit Let is redundant End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething() Dim foo As Long foo = 42 ' [Let] is implicit End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.ObsoleteTypeHintInspection
member.summary: Flags declarations where a type hint is used in place of an 'As' clause.
member.why: Type hints were made obsolete when declaration syntax introduced the 'As' keyword. Prefer explicit type names over type hint symbols.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething() Dim foo$ foo = "some string" End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething() Dim foo As String foo = "some string" End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.OnLocalErrorInspection
member.summary: Flags obsolete 'On Local Error' statements.
member.why: All errors are "local" - the keyword is redundant/confusing and should be removed.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething() On Local Error GoTo ErrHandler ' ... Exit Sub ErrHandler: ' ... End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething() On Error GoTo ErrHandler ' ... Exit Sub ErrHandler: ' ... End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.OptionBaseInspection
member.summary: Flags modules that specify Option Base 1.
member.why: Implicit array lower bound is 0 by default, and Option Base 1 makes it 1. While compelling in a 1-based environment like the Excel object model, having an implicit lower bound of 1 for implicitly-sized user arrays does not change the fact that arrays are always better off with explicit boundaries. Because 0 is always the lower array bound in many other programming languages, this option may trip a reader/maintainer with a different background.
member.example:
Option Explicit Option Base 1
Public Sub DoSomething() Dim foo(10) As Long ' implicit lower bound is 1, array has 10 items. ' ... End Sub

Option Explicit Public Sub DoSomething() Dim foo(10) As Long ' implicit lower bound is 0, array has 11 items. Dim bar(1 To 10) As Long ' explicit lower bound removes all ambiguities, Option Base is redundant. ' ... End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.OptionExplicitInspection
member.summary: Flags modules that omit Option Explicit.
member.why: This option makes variable declarations mandatory. Without it, a typo gets compiled as a new on-the-spot Variant/Empty variable with a new name. Omitting this option amounts to refusing the little help the VBE can provide with compile-time validation.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething() ' ... End Sub

Option Explicit
Public Sub DoSomething() ' ... End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.ParameterCanBeByValInspection
member.summary: Flags parameters that are passed by reference (ByRef), but could be passed by value (ByVal).
member.why: Explicitly specifying a ByVal modifier on a parameter makes the intent explicit: this parameter is not meant to be assigned. In contrast, a parameter that is passed by reference (implicitly, or explicitly ByRef) makes it ambiguous from the calling code's standpoint, whether the procedure might re-assign these ByRef values and introduce a bug.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As Long, bar As Long) Debug.Print foo, bar End Sub
Option Explicit Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As long, ByRef bar As Long) bar = foo * 2 ' ByRef parameter assignment: passing it ByVal could introduce a bug. Debug.Print foo, bar End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.ParameterNotUsedInspection
member.summary: Identifies parameter declarations that are not used.
member.why: Declarations that are not used anywhere should probably be removed.
member.warning: Not all unused parameters can/should be removed: ignore any inspection results for event handler procedures and interface members that Rubberduck isn't recognizing as such.
member.example:
Option Explicit
Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As Long, ByVal bar As Long) Debug.Print foo End Sub
Option Explicit Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As Long, ByVal bar As Long) Debug.Print foo, bar End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.ProcedureCanBeWrittenAsFunctionInspection
member.summary: Warns about 'Sub' procedures that could be refactored into a 'Function'.
member.why: Idiomatic VB code uses 'Function' procedures to return a single value. If the procedure isn't side-effecting, consider writing is as a 'Function' rather than a 'Sub' the returns a result through a 'ByRef' parameter.
member.example:
Option Explicit
Public Sub DoSomething(ByRef result As Long) ' ... result = 42 End Sub
Option Explicit Public Function DoSomething() As Long ' ... DoSomething = 42 End Function

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.ProcedureNotUsedInspection
member.summary: Locates procedures that are never invoked from user code.
member.why: Unused procedures are dead code that should probably be removed. Note, a procedure may be effectively "not used" in code, but attached to some Shape object in the host document: in such cases the inspection result should be ignored. An event handler procedure that isn't being resolved as such, may also wrongly trigger this inspection.
member.warning: Not all unused procedures can/should be removed: ignore any inspection results for event handler procedures and interface members that Rubberduck isn't recognizing as such.
member.example:
Option Explicit
Public Sub DoSomething() ' macro is attached to a worksheet Shape. End Sub

Option Explicit
'@Ignore ProcedureNotUsed Public Sub DoSomething() As Long ' macro is attached to a worksheet Shape. End Sub

member.name: M:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.ProcedureNotUsedInspection.IsPublicModuleMember(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Rubberduck.Parsing.Symbols.Declaration},Rubberduck.Parsing.Symbols.Declaration)
member.remarks: We cannot determine whether exposed members of standard modules are called or not, so we assume they are instead of flagging them as "never called".

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.RedundantByRefModifierInspection
member.summary: Identifies redundant ByRef modifiers.
member.why: Out of convention or preference, explicit ByRef modifiers could be considered redundant since they are the implicit default. This inspection can ensure the consistency of the convention.
member.example:
Option Explicit
Public Sub DoSomething(ByRef foo As Long) foo = foo + 17 Debug.Print foo End Sub
Option Explicit Public Sub DoSomething(foo As Long) foo = foo + 17 Debug.Print foo End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.RedundantOptionInspection
member.summary: Identifies redundant module options that are set to their implicit default.
member.why: Module options that are redundant can be safely removed. Disable this inspection if your convention is to explicitly specify them; a future inspection may be used to enforce consistently explicit module options.
member.example:
Option Explicit Option Base 0 Option Compare Binary
Public Sub DoSomething() End Sub

Option Explicit
Public Sub DoSomething() End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.SelfAssignedDeclarationInspection
member.summary: Identifies auto-assigned object declarations.
member.why: Auto-assigned objects are automatically re-created as soon as they are referenced. It is therefore impossible to set one such reference to 'Nothing' and then verifying whether the object 'Is Nothing': it will never be. This behavior is potentially confusing and bug-prone.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething() Dim c As New Collection Set c = Nothing c.Add 42 ' no error 91 raised Debug.Print c.Count ' 1 Set c = Nothing Debug.Print c Is Nothing ' False End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething() Dim c As Collection Set c = New Collection Set c = Nothing c.Add 42 ' error 91 Debug.Print c.Count ' error 91 Set c = Nothing Debug.Print c Is Nothing ' True End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.ShadowedDeclarationInspection
member.summary: Identifies identifiers that hide/"shadow" other identifiers otherwise accessible in that scope.
member.why: Global namespace contains a number of perfectly legal identifier names that user code can use. But using these names in user code effectively "hides" the global ones. In general, avoid shadowing global-scope identifiers if possible.
member.example:
Private MsgBox As String ' hides the global-scope VBA.Interaction.MsgBox function in this module.
Public Sub DoSomething() MsgBox = "Test" ' refers to the module variable in scope. VBA.Interaction.MsgBox MsgBox ' global function now needs to be fully qualified to be accessed. End Sub

Private message As String
Public Sub DoSomething() message = "Test" MsgBox message ' VBA.Interaction module qualifier is optional. End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.StepIsNotSpecifiedInspection
member.summary: Locates 'For' loops where the 'Step' token is omitted.
member.why: Out of convention or preference, explicit 'Step' specifiers could be considered mandatory; this inspection can ensure the consistency of the convention.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething() Dim i As Long For i = 1 To 100 ' Step is implicitly 1 ' ... Next End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething() Dim i As Long For i = 1 To 100 Step 1 ' explicit 'Step 1' could also be considered redundant. ' ... Next End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.StepOneIsRedundantInspection
member.summary: Locates 'For' loops where the 'Step' token is specified with the default increment value (1).
member.why: Out of convention or preference, explicit 'Step 1' specifiers could be considered redundant; this inspection can ensure the consistency of the convention.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething() Dim i As Long For i = 1 To 100 Step 1 ' 1 being the implicit default, 'Step 1' could be considered redundant. ' ... Next End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething() Dim i As Long For i = 1 To 100 ' implicit: 'Step 1' ' ... Next End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.StopKeywordInspection
member.summary: Locates 'Stop' instructions in user code.
member.why: While a great debugging tool, 'Stop' instructions should not be reachable in production code; this inspection makes it easy to locate them all.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething() ' ... Stop ' halts execution on-the-spot, bringing up the VBE; not very user-friendly! '.... End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething() ' ... 'Stop ' the commented-out statement isn't executable. Could also be simply removed. ' ... End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.UnassignedVariableUsageInspection
member.summary: Warns when a variable is referenced prior to being assigned.
member.why: An uninitialized variable is being read, but since it's never assigned, the only value ever read would be the data type's default initial value. Reading a variable that was never written to in any code path (especially if Option Explicit isn't specified), is likely to be a bug.
member.remarks: This inspection may produce false positives when the variable is an array, or if it's passed by reference (ByRef) to a procedure that assigns it.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething() Dim i As Long Debug.Print i ' i was never assigned End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething() Dim i As Long i = 42 Debug.Print i End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.UndeclaredVariableInspection
member.summary: Warns about implicit local variables that are used but never declared.
member.why: If this code compiles, then Option Explicit is omitted and compile-time validation is easily forfeited, even accidentally (e.g. typos).
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething() foo = 42 ' foo is not declared ' ... End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething() Dim foo As Long foo = 42 ' ... End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.UnderscoreInPublicClassModuleMemberInspection
member.summary: Warns about public class members with an underscore in their names.
member.why: The public interface of any class module can be implemented by any other class module; if the public interface contains names with underscores, other classes cannot implement it - the code will not compile. Avoid underscores; prefer PascalCase names.
member.example:
'@Interface
Public Sub Do_Something() ' underscore in name makes the interface non-implementable. End Sub

'@Interface
Public Sub DoSomething() ' PascalCase identifiers are never a problem. End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.UnhandledOnErrorResumeNextInspection
member.summary: Finds instances of 'On Error Resume Next' that don't have a corresponding 'On Error GoTo 0' to restore error handling.
member.why: 'On Error Resume Next' should be constrained to a limited number of instructions, otherwise it supresses error handling for the rest of the procedure; 'On Error GoTo 0' reinstates error handling. This inspection helps treating 'Resume Next' and 'GoTo 0' as a code block (similar to 'With...End With'), essentially.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething() On Error Resume Next ' error handling is never restored in this scope. ' ... End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething() On Error Resume Next ' ... On Error GoTo 0 End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.UnreachableCaseInspection.UnreachableCaseInspection
member.summary: Flags 'Case' blocks that are semantically unreachable.
member.why: Unreachable code is certainly unintended, and is probably either redundant, or a bug.
member.remarks: Not all unreachable 'Case' blocks may be flagged, depending on expression complexity.
member.example: Private Sub Example(ByVal value As Long) Select Case value Case 0 To 99 ' ... Case 50 ' unreachable: case is covered by a preceding condition. ' ... Case Is < 100 ' ... Case < 0 ' unreachable: case is covered by a preceding condition. ' ... End Select End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.UntypedFunctionUsageInspection
member.summary: Flags uses of a number of specific string-centric but Variant-returning functions in various standard library modules.
member.why: Several functions in the standard library take a Variant parameter and return a Variant result, but an equivalent string-returning function taking a string parameter exists and should probably be preferred.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As Double) Debug.Print Format(foo, "Currency") ' Strings.Format function returns a Variant. End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething(ByVal foo As Double) Debug.Print Format$(CStr(foo), "Currency") ' Strings.Format$ function returns a String. End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.UseMeaningfulNameInspection
member.summary: Warns about identifiers that have names that are likely to be too short, disemvoweled, or appended with a numeric suffix.
member.why: Meaningful, pronounceable, unabbreviated names read better and leave less room for interpretation. Moreover, names suffixed with a number can indicate the need to look into an array, collection, or dictionary data structure.
member.example: Public Sub CpFrmtRls(ByVal rng1 As Range, ByVal rng2 As Range) ' ... End Sub
Public Sub CopyFormatRules(ByVal source As Range, ByVal destination As Range) ' ... End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.VariableNotAssignedInspection
member.summary: Warns about variables that are never assigned.
member.why: A variable that is never assigned is probably a sign of a bug. This inspection may yield false positives if the variable is assigned through a ByRef parameter assignment, or if UserForm controls fail to resolve, references to these controls in code-behind can be flagged as unassigned and undeclared variables.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething() Dim value As Long ' declared, but not assigned ' ... End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething() Dim value As Long value = 42 ' ... End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.VariableNotUsedInspection
member.summary: Warns about variables that are never referenced.
member.why: A variable can be declared and even assigned, but if its value is never referenced, it's effectively an unused variable.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething() Dim value As Long ' declared value = 42 ' assigned ' ... but never rerenced End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething() Dim value As Long value = 42 Debug.Print value End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.VariableTypeNotDeclaredInspection
member.summary: Warns about variables declared without an explicit data type.
member.why: A variable declared without an explicit data type is implicitly a Variant/Empty until it is assigned.
member.example: Public Sub DoSomething() Dim value ' implicit Variant value = 42 ' ... End Sub
Public Sub DoSomething() Dim value As Long value = 42 ' ... End Sub

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.Concrete.WriteOnlyPropertyInspection
member.summary: Warns about properties that don't expose a 'Property Get' accessor.
member.why: Write-only properties are suspicious: if the client code is able to set a property, it should be allowed to read that property as well. Class design guidelines and best practices generally recommend against write-only properties.
member.example:
Private internalFoo As Long
Public Property Let Foo(ByVal value As Long) internalFoo = value End Property

Private internalFoo As Long
Public Property Let Foo(ByVal value As Long) internalFoo = value End Property
Public Property Get Foo() As Long Foo = internalFoo End Property

member.name: M:Rubberduck.Inspections.VariableRequiresSetAssignmentEvaluator.RequiresSetAssignment(Rubberduck.Parsing.Symbols.IdentifierReference,Rubberduck.Parsing.VBA.IDeclarationFinderProvider)
member.summary: Determines whether the 'Set' keyword is required (whether it's present or not) for the specified identifier reference.

member.name: T:Rubberduck.Inspections.QuickFixes.RemoveUnusedDeclarationQuickFix
member.summary: A code inspection quickfix that removes an unused identifier declaration.
